wikipedia_page.main: Sir John Scott (4 June 1841 – 1 March 1904) was an English judge who became, amongst other titles, Deputy Judge Advocate-General and later Judicial Advisor to the Khedive in his adopted home, Egypt. He was also known as a cricketer in his youth, active from 1861 to 1863 when he played for Oxford University.  Scott was renowned for wit, humour and humanity.  His fame position in the exalted annals of imperial legal jurisprudence contributed to the successful legal defence of British Egypt during two world wars.  A sure touch, and a deft hand, he articulated a source of justice residing in the everlasting verities of English common law.
